introduction.value: Test suite for ChibiOS/RT. The purpose of this suite is to perform unit tests on the RT modules and to converge to 100% code coverage through successive improvements.

description.value: The functionality of the system layer and port interface is tested. Basic RT functionality is taken for granted or this test suite could not even be executed. Errors in implementation are detected by executing this sequence with the state checker enabled (CH_DBG_STATE_CHECKER=TRUE).
The system self-test functionality is invoked in order to make an initial system state assessment and for coverage.
Testing Ready List integrity.
Testing Virtual Timers List integrity.
Testing Registry List integrity.
Testing Port-defined integrity.
The critical zones API is invoked for coverage.
Testing chSysGetStatusAndLockX() and chSysRestoreStatusX(), non reentrant case.

code.value: sts = chSysGetStatusAndLockX(); chSysRestoreStatusX(sts);

description.value: Testing chSysGetStatusAndLockX() and chSysRestoreStatusX(), reentrant case.
Testing chSysUnconditionalLock().
Testing chSysUnconditionalUnlock().
Testing from ISR context using a virtual timer.
The interrupts handling API is invoked for coverage.
Testing chSysSuspend(), chSysDisable() and chSysEnable().
The functionality of the API @p chVTGetSystemTimeX() is tested.
A System Tick Counter increment is expected, the test simply hangs if it does not happen.
This sequence tests the ChibiOS/NIL functionalities related to threading.
The functionality of @p chThdSleep() and derivatives is tested.
The current system time is read then a sleep is performed for 100 system ticks and on exit the system time is verified again.
The current system time is read then a sleep is performed for 100000 microseconds and on exit the system time is verified again.
The current system time is read then a sleep is performed for 100 milliseconds and on exit the system time is verified again.
The current system time is read then a sleep is performed for 1 second and on exit the system time is verified again.
Function chThdSleepUntil() is tested with a timeline of "now" + 100 ticks.

brief.value: Ready List functionality, threads priority order.

description.value: Five threads, are enqueued in the ready list and atomically executed. The test expects the threads to perform their operations in correct priority order regardless of the initial order.
Creating 5 threads with increasing priority, execution sequence is tested.
Creating 5 threads with decreasing priority, execution sequence is tested.
Creating 5 threads with pseudo-random priority, execution sequence is tested.
A series of priority changes are performed on the current thread in order to verify that the priority change happens as expected.
Thread priority is increased by one then a check is performed.
Thread priority is returned to the previous value then a check is performed.

brief.value: Priority change test with Priority Inheritance.

description.value: A series of priority changes are performed on the current thread in order to verify that the priority change happens as expected.
Simulating a priority boost situation (prio > realprio).
Raising thread priority above original priority but below the boosted level.
Raising thread priority above the boosted level.
Restoring original conditions.
This sequence tests the ChibiOS/RT functionalities related to threads suspend/resume.
The functionality of chThdSuspendTimeoutS() and chThdResumeI() is tested.
The function chThdSuspendTimeoutS() is invoked, the thread is remotely resumed with message @p MSG_OK. On return the message and the state of the reference are tested.
The function chThdSuspendTimeoutS() is invoked, the thread is not resumed so a timeout must occur. On return the message and the state of the reference are tested.
This sequence tests the ChibiOS/NIL functionalities related to counter semaphores.
Wait, Signal and Reset primitives are tested. The testing thread does not trigger a state change.
The function chSemWait() is invoked, after return the counter and the returned message are tested.
The function chSemSignal() is invoked, after return the counter is tested.

code.value: chSemSignal(&sem1); test_assert_lock(chSemGetCounterI(&sem1) == 1, "wrong counter value");

description.value: The function chSemReset() is invoked, after return the counter is tested.

code.value: chSemReset(&sem1, 2); test_assert_lock(chSemGetCounterI(&sem1) == 2, "wrong counter value");

description.value: Five threads with randomized priorities are enqueued to a semaphore then awakened one at time. The test expects that the threads reach their goal in FIFO order or priority order depending on the @p CH_CFG_USE_SEMAPHORES_PRIORITY configuration setting.
Five threads are created with mixed priority levels (not increasing nor decreasing). Threads enqueue on a semaphore initialized to zero.
The semaphore is signaled 5 times. The thread activation sequence is tested.
This sequence tests the ChibiOS/NIL functionalities related to mailboxes.
The mailbox normal API is tested without triggering blocking conditions.
Testing the mailbox size.

code.value: test_assert_lock(chMBGetFreeCountI(&mb1) == MB_SIZE, "wrong size");

description.value: Resetting the mailbox, conditions are checked, no errors expected.
Filling the mailbox using chMBPost() and chMBPostAhead() once, no errors expected.
Testing intermediate conditions. Data pointers must be aligned, semaphore counters are checked.
Emptying the mailbox using chMBFetch(), no errors expected.
Posting and then fetching one more message, no errors expected.
Testing final conditions. Data pointers must be aligned to buffer start, semaphore counters are checked.
The mailbox I-Class API is tested without triggering blocking conditions.
Testing the mailbox size.

code.value: test_assert_lock(chMBGetFreeCountI(&mb1) == MB_SIZE, "wrong size");

description.value: Resetting the mailbox, conditions are checked, no errors expected.
Filling the mailbox using chMBPostI() and chMBPostAheadI() once, no errors expected.
Testing intermediate conditions. Data pointers must be aligned, semaphore counters are checked.
Emptying the mailbox using chMBFetchI(), no errors expected.
Posting and then fetching one more message, no errors expected.
Testing final conditions. Data pointers must be aligned to buffer start, semaphore counters are checked.
The mailbox API is tested for timeouts.
Filling the mailbox.
Testing chMBPost(), chMBPostI(), chMBPostAhead() and chMBPostAheadI() timeout.
Resetting the mailbox.

code.value: chMBReset(&mb1);

description.value: Testing chMBFetch() and chMBFetchI() timeout.
This sequence tests the ChibiOS/NIL functionalities related to memory pools.

brief.value: Loading and emptying a memory pool.

description.value: The memory pool functionality is tested by loading and emptying it, all conditions are tested.
Adding the objects to the pool using chPoolLoadArray().

code.value: chPoolLoadArray(&mp1, objects, MEMORY_POOL_SIZE);

description.value: Emptying the pool using chPoolAlloc().

code.value: for (i = 0; i < MEMORY_POOL_SIZE; i++) test_assert(chPoolAlloc(&mp1) != NULL, "list empty");

description.value: Now must be empty.

code.value: test_assert(chPoolAlloc(&mp1) == NULL, "list not empty");

description.value: Adding the objects to the pool using chPoolFree().

code.value: for (i = 0; i < MEMORY_POOL_SIZE; i++) chPoolFree(&mp1, &objects[i]);

description.value: Emptying the pool using chPoolAlloc() again.

code.value: for (i = 0; i < MEMORY_POOL_SIZE; i++) test_assert(chPoolAlloc(&mp1) != NULL, "list empty");

description.value: Now must be empty again.

code.value: test_assert(chPoolAlloc(&mp1) == NULL, "list not empty");

description.value: Covering the case where a provider is unable to return more memory.

code.value: chPoolObjectInit(&mp1, sizeof (uint32_t), null_provider); test_assert(chPoolAlloc(&mp1) == NULL, "provider returned memory");

brief.value: Loading and emptying a guarded memory pool without waiting.

description.value: The memory pool functionality is tested by loading and emptying it, all conditions are tested.
Adding the objects to the pool using chGuardedPoolLoadArray().

code.value: chGuardedPoolLoadArray(&gmp1, objects, MEMORY_POOL_SIZE);

description.value: Emptying the pool using chGuardedPoolAllocTimeout().

code.value: for (i = 0; i < MEMORY_POOL_SIZE; i++) test_assert(chGuardedPoolAllocTimeout(&gmp1, TIME_IMMEDIATE) != NULL, "list empty");

description.value: Now must be empty.

code.value: test_assert(chGuardedPoolAllocTimeout(&gmp1, TIME_IMMEDIATE) == NULL, "list not empty");

description.value: Adding the objects to the pool using chGuardedPoolFree().

code.value: for (i = 0; i < MEMORY_POOL_SIZE; i++) chGuardedPoolFree(&gmp1, &objects[i]);

description.value: Emptying the pool using chGuardedPoolAllocTimeout() again.

code.value: for (i = 0; i < MEMORY_POOL_SIZE; i++) test_assert(chGuardedPoolAllocTimeout(&gmp1, TIME_IMMEDIATE) != NULL, "list empty");

description.value: Now must be empty again.

code.value: test_assert(chGuardedPoolAllocTimeout(&gmp1, TIME_IMMEDIATE) == NULL, "list not empty");

description.value: The timeout features for the Guarded Memory Pools is tested.
Trying to allocate with 100mS timeout, must fail because the pool is empty.

code.value: test_assert(chGuardedPoolAllocTimeout(&gmp1, MS2ST(100)) == NULL, "list not empty");

description.value: This sequence tests the ChibiOS/NIL functionalities related to memory heaps.

Series of allocations/deallocations are performed in carefully designed sequences in order to stimulate all the possible code paths inside the allocator. The test expects to find the heap back to the initial status after each sequence.
Testing initial conditions, the heap must not be fragmented and one free block present.

code.value: test_assert(chHeapStatus(&test_heap, &sz, NULL) == 1, "heap fragmented");

description.value: Trying to allocate an block bigger than available space, an error is expected.

code.value: p1 = chHeapAlloc(&test_heap, HEAP_SIZE * 2); test_assert(p1 == NULL, "allocation not failed");

description.value: Single block allocation using chHeapAlloc() then the block is freed using chHeapFree(), must not fail.
Using chHeapStatus() to assess the heap state. There must be at least one free block of sufficient size.
Allocating then freeing in the same order.
Allocating then freeing in reverse order.
Small fragments handling. Checking the behavior when allocating blocks with size not multiple of alignment unit.
Skipping a fragment, the first fragment in the list is too small so the allocator must pick the second one.
Allocating the whole available space.
Testing final conditions. The heap geometry must be the same than the one registered at beginning.

code.value: test_assert(chHeapStatus(&test_heap, &n, NULL) == 1, "heap fragmented"); test_assert(n == sz, "size changed");

description.value: The default heap is pre-allocated in the system. We test base functionality.
Single block allocation using chHeapAlloc() then the block is freed using chHeapFree(), must not fail.
Testing allocation failure.

code.value: p1 = chHeapAlloc(NULL, (size_t)-256); test_assert(p1 == NULL, "allocation not failed");
